metadata.title: Convert Bits to Tebibytes
metadata.description: Convert bits (b) to tebibytes (TiB) using binary prefixes with exact factors, examples, and notes on when to use binary vs decimal units.

introduction: This converter changes a value in bits into tebibytes (TiB), the binary unit equal to 2^40 bytes. Use it for binary-accurate contexts such as file systems, storage platforms that report in TiB, or engineering documents requiring IEC prefixes.
methodology: Conversion path: bits → bytes (÷8) → TiB (÷1,099,511,627,776). Combined: TiB = bits ÷ (8 × 1,099,511,627,776).
how_is_calculated: Decimal comparison: the same bit value equals 1 TB when using the decimal factor (10^12 bytes).

faqs.question: When should I choose TiB over TB?
faqs.answer: Choose TiB when specifications or software require binary units (powers of two). Choose TB when following SI decimal units (powers of ten). Always match the convention in your documentation or contract.

faqs.question: Does the bit-to-byte factor ever change?
faqs.answer: No. 1 byte = 8 bits in modern usage. Only the prefix (decimal vs binary) changes the divisor for the larger unit.

faqs.question: How should I round large outputs?
faqs.answer: Keep full precision internally. For reporting, round to an appropriate number of significant figures (for example, 2–4) and clearly state the unit (TiB) to avoid ambiguity.

citations.label: NIST — Reference on Units and Prefixes

summary: TiB = bits ÷ (8 × 1,099,511,627,776). Use this for binary-accurate conversions; for decimal TB use 10^12 bytes as the divisor.

glossary.definition: IEC prefixes (Ki, Mi, Gi, Ti) representing powers of two.
